posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It woudn't have been Ottoman 2.0. simply because it cultivated very early close links , either forcefuly or by necessity with the Italian republics. The empire was always the connective link beatween eastern trade and the western naval powers of the Meditterenean. Had it survived more or less intact and with no Turkish Sultanate as a rival in Anatolia, it would eventually lose some influence in the Balkans, and completely lose its Italian holdings, but would keep its relevenace and become more western european in culture and customs and probably start engaging in western dynastic politics, as it did during the Palaiologan era. However the Italian republics like Genoa and Venice would have an increased role in Byzantine afairs and would probably not lose their relevance as they did during the late-renaissance period.

This would lead to a close balance of power in the Mediterenean beatween Aragon, the Angevins and the Byzantine-Ventians/Genoese. This was not the case in our timeline where Aragon with its union with Castille became clearly ascendant in the Med.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14456237
>It would have been fucked over by the Mongol invasions.
Not necessarily. None of the Mongol states lasted for very long at all.
>the poisonous culture of intrigue that polluted the state's governmental apparatus
The path towards absolutism would have taken hold eventually, probably much earlier than what we saw in western Europe.

They only needed to stabilize one of their borders, Balkans or Anatolia, in order to guarantee their survival. Good relations with a Christianized Hungarian kingdom and a crushed Bulgaria would see to the west, while a line of defenses along the Anatolian mountain range from Antioch to Trebizond would secure the east. Because of the geography, they could afford to take a lot of beatings as long as they didn't have to fight both at the same time.

I don't claim to know if any one religion's idea of god is true but what makes the most sense to me (through my own fallible reason, subject to change) is this:
Things exist and operate on cause and effect, a chain of causes stretching back infinitely doesn't make sense, therefor there has to be something that's eternal and uncreated that set everything in motion.
The law of conservation of matter, the fact that physical things don't start or stop existing just change form, is a strong case against creation ex nihilo. This leads me to believe that if the first cause is god then everything that exists is a part of god and that he "creates" by acting upon himself.
Consciousness appears to be a fundamental property of the universe rather than arising from matter. Basically, there's no way to prove anything other than the fact that the mind exists, anything else is dependent on being observable by consciousness. If we assume (and I acknowledge that this is an assumption) that consciousness is a fundamental property of existence in the same way matter is then that would make god a conscious being and also solve the problem of an afterlife/reincarnation since consciousness wouldn't cease to exist.

The issue with defaulting to 'energy' as a basic substrate is the unwieldy nature of its primary meaning. What we refer to as 'energy' is but a abstraction representation of the innate capacity of action that a given object possesses, i.e. of something influencing or causing a change in something else in a noticeable, observable, or scientifically measurable way (usually in the form of motion, which is the most basic phenomena of observable). But this definition loses its very coherence when we start talking about quantum fields as vectors of influence overlapping one another in spacetime; the ontology ceases to be about 'things' in the material sense and becomes 'digital' in the sense that discrete units of information become the foundation of reality. The overlapping fields are analogous to layers or subsystems of a complex information processing system that, taken together, produces and interprets the content of reality (i.e. of the cosmos). This is pretty much what theoretical physicists, mathematicians, and software programmers spend all their day doing; establishing frameworks or structures for the interpretation of data, and working out the relationships that exist among quantities and qualities (i.e. variables) and how they interact to produce more complex variables and larger or smaller quantities, depending on the operation/interaction.

>>14441139

Now, as even a child can understand, the meaning of information, whether it is linguistic, numerical, or visual, is dependent on the context in which it is presented. 1+1=2 only insomuch as the addition of identical discrete quantities yields a greater quantity which is itself specified as the sum of its antecedents. What this means is that there are necessary preconditions in any information system in order for there to be data; the interpretative apparatus cannot 'emerge' or 'develop' alongside the data, but rather stands behind it and makes it intelligible. Thus, even an A.I. that can 'learn' in the sense that it can develop functions beyond that of the programmer's initial coding is still limited by the constraints of its interpretive nexus, and, hence, the amount of data it can act upon. There can be no 'new' data apart from the discrete units of information that were already present in the system as a baseline, as well as the varying ways of combining them to form larger structures of meaning, itself a process utterly reliant upon the 'architecture' or interpretative grid of the system.

But where does data (i.e. the content reality) come from in the first place? After all, I mentioned above that there can be no 'new' data in the sense of information introduced by the system itself (i.e the contextual framework of rules for interpreting reality) outside that which it has been initially supplied. Both data and the program which interprets it must themselves be necessarily supplied by an external source, who in everyday software production and maintenance we refer to as the programmer. It is he or she that both writes the program as well as supplies the basic units of code that serve as signals for the conveying of information.

This elaborate example depicts the main thrust of the contingency argument as presented in modern terms.

>>14442857
All this talk about "self-configuring", "self-processing", or "self-determining" reality simply proves what I had suspected early on: namely, that both you and Langan subscribe to a type of Spinozist monism. You assert that the prescriptive principle which organizes information and delimits meaning within reality is identical with the content of reality; the distinction, as you hold it, is a conceptual one rather than an actual one.

The problem with this view is that it conflates the order of being (the ordo essendi) with the order of knowing (the ordo cognoscendi). That is, you deny the logical and temporal priority of that which norms and delimits information as necessarily preceding that which it acts upon, or the modal entity that conveys or communicates information. The source always precedes the derivative; the cause always precedes the effect.

What Langan and his forebears (Liebniz, Fichte, Schelling, Hegel, Schopenhauer, and Bergson) believe is that consciousness and the volition exercised by rational agents is ultimately what is determinative of reality; the cosmos and its contents are self-interpreting closed system. The issue with this is that the irreversibility of numerous physical processes, as well as the degradation of information coherence and structure over time (i.e. entropy), necessarily disproves it. The universe, just like a software program, displays internal evidence of having a cause prior to and external to itself.

Just as mathematicians can alter the semantic and relational framework within which they examine quantities and variables by revising or replacing the terms (whether they be numerical values or operations therein performed as represented by symbols) that delineate meaning, so too can a programmer delimit and alter the possible meanings that data can possess within the context of the information processing system as a whole. Bottom line? Meaning is dependent or contingent upon a semantic network that precedes it

But this semantic framework is but one of an innumerable series of possible frameworks that could be employed to produce 'information', with meaning determined differently in each separate case. Thus, for meaning to be 'delimited' or 'fixed' in the sense that it holds true from moment to moment and is equally accessible to all observers with properly functioning sensory, perceptory, and cognitive 'equipment', a 'truth-maker' or 'law-giver', i.e. an organizing and sustaining intelligence that regulates and determines meaning, is necessary. A norming norm whose presence and powers of action are not contingent upon anything prior to it, as with a semantic/interpretative framework's relationship to data, but is itself the source of all content and context.

This is what the argument from contingency is really getting at. Though we may imagine an infinity of possible realities, we, as human beings, experience only one shared reality whose laws are fixed and regular. This is due to the determinative action of a volitional being whose existence is necessarily prior to and transcendent of said reality and its particular constraints. Hence, God is sovereign over all creation, and it is He who lays the foundations of the earth and the boundaries of the sea. Insomuch as the Bible describes Him as being 'external' to the Creation, it is validly describing the truth that an unbounded information source cannot be exhaustively contained or communicated to a bounded reality, even via its modal manifestations.

The upshot of all this is that the very existence of 'facts', 'truths', or 'information' that we recognize as having validity beyond our own subjective preferences is sufficient proof of the existence of God. That is why the Scripture can affirm that the whole of Creation testifies of the LORD, so that men are without excuse so their unbelief.

>>14444628
Gödel's incompleteness theorems are two theorems of mathematical logic that are concerned with the limits of provability in formal axiomatic theories. These results, published by Kurt Gödel in 1931, are important both in mathematical logic and in the philosophy of mathematics. The theorems are widely, but not universally, interpreted as showing that Hilbert's program to find a complete and consistent set of axioms for all mathematics is impossible. The first incompleteness theorem states that no consistent system of axioms whose theorems can be listed by an effective procedure is capable of proving all truths about the arithmetic of natural numbers. For any such consistent formal system, there will always be statements about natural numbers that are true, but that are unprovable within the system. The second incompleteness theorem, an extension of the first, shows that the system cannot demonstrate its own consistency.

Let me explain a bit further.

What caused the big bang?
Something. That's what.
Either it was a result of a previous universe that existed that collapsed or there is some other explanation.
It doesn't really matter.
Because whatever that is also has the same question of: what caused that to happen?
And this goes backwards an infinite number of times.
Everything is the result of a prior action.
Nothing can move on its own.
Except for some thing called a First Mover.
That first mover does not obey any logic we can conceive so far.
It doesn't obey any logic we can conceive of conceiving in the future.
It's illogical.
Yet it is also logical to think that something started all of this since we are here right now.
Unless time is a loop with no beginning or end.
But then: where did the loop come from?
From something outside time, and outside all logical notions of cause and effect.
A thing which should exist because here we are, but is utterly inscrutable to our minds.
That's a god.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Catholic/Orthodox theology of images is that man-made images (paintings, statues, etc.) are not worshiped but venerated, and that the honor paid to an image passes to its prototype (that whom it depicts). They believe that the cultic use of images (bowing, kissing, processing, praying) is justified by God becoming man, as Christ's human body is understood as an image in a manner that is analogous to man-made images. I won't be making an argument that these distinctions are false, but examining where their logic leads, particularly in relation to man-made images of Christ. I am not also seeking to demonstrate that man-made images in themselves are wrong. Definitions: "worship" is the degree of honor due only to God; "veneration" is a lesser degree of honor which can be given to creatures and objects.

1. If the honor paid to a man-made image passes to its prototype, then worship paid to a man-made image would pass to its prototype. So if a person worshiped a painting of Jesus as if it were God, this worship would pass to Jesus. Catholic/Orthodox theology would state that it is forbidden to worship a man-made image, a piece of wood or stone, as if it were God; but this is still the logic of this understanding of the relation between image and prototype.

2. Given that worship given to a man-made image of Jesus would pass to Jesus, but this is forbidden, it means that there is a fundamental distinction between man-made images and the image of Christ's human body. No one would claim that if Jesus were standing physically in front of them, that the proper response would not be to worship him as God, despite him being present in an image. But this is denied for man-made images. So man-made images and Christ's body are both "images" only in the broadest sense of the term, and are not actually analogous to each other.

(1/2)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14456947
3. If worship cannot be paid to a man-made image of God, that is, if one cannot worship a painting or statue as if it were God, this means that God can only be worshiped without images. If one wishes to worship God, they cannot do so by utilizing a man-made image. One could venerate God through a man-made image, but one cannot worship God through a man-made image. God can only be worshiped without man-made images. Frankly, I think this point alone vitiates the fundamental claim of iconoclasts.

4. This begs the question of why I would want to venerate God through a man-made image when the proper response of the soul to God is to worship him. If Christ were physically before me, I would not want to simply venerate him, that is, to give him the honor I would give to merely a man. He is my God, and I would want to worship him as my God. So by utilizing a man-made image of Christ, I am actually unable to pay Christ the honor that he is properly due. Perhaps one could say there is worth in, at times, giving God less honor than what he deserves; this strikes me as impious.

5. A way around this would be to claim that worship of images is actually acceptable. In which case, you are worshiping a rock or a piece of wood as if it is your God. Your intention is indeed that the true God is worshiped, but you are still paying the worship due to the living God to a rock or to a stone. The idea that this would not constitute idolatry is absurd.

(2/2)

Part of the destruction of the peoples of Canaan was punishment for their sin and a cleansing of the land. Two verses indicate this rather clearly:

"Then the LORD said to [Abraham], 'Know for certain that your descendants will be strangers in a country not their own, and they will be enslaved and mistreated four hundred years. But I will punish the nation they serve as slaves, and afterward they will come out with great possessions.... In the fourth generation your descendants will come back here, for the sin of the Amorites has not yet reached its full measure....'" (Genesis 15:13-14, 16)

"Do not defile yourselves in any of these ways, because this is how the nations that I am going to drive out before you became defiled. Even the land was defiled; so I punished it for its sin, and the land vomited out its inhabitants. But you must keep my decrees and my laws. The native-born and the aliens living among you must not do any of these detestable things, for all these things were done by the people who lived in the land before you, and the land became defiled. And if you defile the land, it will vomit you out as it vomited out the nations that were before you" (Leviticus 18:24-28)

So we must view the Israelite Conquest, in part, as the sword of God's punishment for sin, if we are to take the Bible seriously.

God, not man, established the law of marriage; therefore, marriage is holy. In the marriage union, the husband and wife become one flesh, which St. Paul calls “a great mystery” (Eph 5:32). This mystery is so great and wonderful that a man will leave his father and mother with their blessing, and be joined to a woman in marriage. This great mystery points to the greater mystery: the marriage of Christ and His Bride, the Church (Eph 5:22-33). For He left His Father and became Man to seek a Bride. He loved His Bride and gave Himself for her. And in his divine vision of the new heaven and earth, the apostle John saw this Bride, the “New Jerusalem, coming down out of heaven from God, prepared as a bride adorned for her husband” (Rev 21:1, 2).

>In the early Middle Ages, Irish monks were actively involved in missionary work. >Henry II was elevated from the rank of Margrave (Markgraf) to that of Duke (Herzog) in 1156. He moved his residence from Klosterneuburg to Vienna and required a monastery for his new city. In the Middle Ages, monasteries were not only places for prayer, but also and above all, repositories of knowledge. The foundation of a monastery gave the ruler support for his administration (for example, schools to educate competent scribes). It also provided a library, a hospice and old age home, architects, educated men, and priests to conduct services in the new ducal city. The "Schotten" would also be involved with the University of Vienna, which was founded in 1365.

>>14452237
It was a neutral hunting hamlet in the geographic center of the peninsula. The Habsburgs used to have a traveling court but they had to pick a capital because a central bureaucracy needed to be formed. If they went with Toledo or Valladolid the Portuguese and Aragonese would be mad. If they went with Lisbon then the Castilians and Aragonese would be mad. If they went with Zaragoza or Barcelona then the Castilians and Portuguese would be mad. I would have preferred a capital on the tagus river myself for easier access to Lisbon but the remoteness of Madrid helped ensure it would be neutral and only important due to it being the seat of the king. Madrid only became the largest city in Spain in the early 20th century

From adolescence, black female slaves were subjected
to their master's desire for them to reproduce because increasing the
number of slaves resulted in an increase in profits.9 Whether it be
forceful or subtle, there were instances of sexual intervention that

The physical as well as psychological struggles that came with
childbearing were enormous for enslaved women. They were expected
to put the needs of the master and his family before those of their own
children. The slave mothers on large plantations returned to the fields
soon after giving birth, leaving their child to be raised by others.11 On
a smaller plantation, the responsibilities of slave mothers were simply
added to their usual duties.12 Slave mothers often intentionally stayed
in bondage to avoid being separated from their child, while their male
counterparts attempted to escape.13 Tragically, the enslaved mothers
faced the possibility of witnessing their daughters suffer the same fate
of essentially being a breeder for the slave master.
In addition to being a slave breeder they were also the subjects
of experimental gynecological and reproductive surgeries, which were
often performed with no anesthesia.14 Some sources estimate that 58%
of all enslaved women aged 15–30 years old were sexually assaulted by
their slave owners and other white men.

Jezebel stereotype was particularly common during slavery, when
black women’s bodies were socially controlled as sexual objects based
on racist, classist, and sexist ideologies.24 Within the bounds of slavery,
masters often felt it was their right to engage in sexual activity with
enslaved black women.25 Sometimes, enslaved black women acquiesced
to advances hoping that such relationships would increase the chances
that they or their children would be liberated by the master.26

In West Europe on the other hand the Y-DNA replacement was often almost complete.

>>14455079
Probably good for most, but short for others.

Initially, the Chola decided to send their fleet to the SEA region to protect valuable trade routes to China. Eventually, they found it easier to simply raid the cities and do away with any polity that could form and potentially rival their influence. From there, the Chola began launching proper invasions on modern day Malaysia. Rajendra I forced the surrender of Srivijaya and married into the royal family. This was after they had conquered up the Indian coast and into the northeast, following the coastline to Burma.

these invasions resulted in the destruction of a few major cities in the region. But the Chola did a good job of spreading their culture to the east, especially Buddhism and Hinduism, as well as some of the first ever writing scripts to reach SEA. They patronized the arts, as evidenced by primary source inscriptions and artifacts characterized by a Indian-Sino fusion. Urban centers likely recovered and became important in trade, again evidenced by inscriptions. Still, it seems that the Tamil traders encroached on the region and there was a pretty clear benefit for the colonizers.

Assuming you want an actual answer and you're not just being a faggot: two things unironically did this.

>Potatoes.
During the colonial exchange potatoes were introduced to Europe and while on continental Europe the spread and consumption of potatoes met resistance (people thought they were poisonous), in the UK they were forced onto the population. The idea was you, you as a landlord, could force your tenants on a miniscule scrap of land (while you expanded your own wool and wheat production) and they could still sustain themselves on nothing but potatoes. It didn't even need to be fertile; potatoes would grow. Peasants could be fed effectively nothing but potatoes, a bit of butter or cheese, and an odd vegetable from the garden. This didn't stop with peasant tenants: factory workers, miners, smiths, everyone was being fed potatoes. This forced monotonous working class diet effectively destroyed any previous cullinary developments.
All the 'good' potato recipes were formulated by the French, Spanish, Italians, and American Colonists, at a later point.

>WW2 Military Surplus.
*Ironically, AFTER WW2 a lot of the food culture of America was negatively impacted by the surplus & convenience culture produced by the times. People had an obsession with the "latest in home economic technologies" like frozen foods, microwaves, instant-meals, dehydrated foods, canned foods, things made inexpensive and available by the rationing and converted military infrastructure. There was both a fashionably 'trendy' aspect to it, but also a genuine superstition where lots of people thought pre-packaged meals were somehow "more hygienic" (bit of trivia, but Trump holds this belief).

*I say ironically because leading up to and during WW2 food standards in America were actually improving. The Federal Government thought it was imperative that the American Citizen have access to nutritious food to ensure a healthy stock of robust soldiers to draft.

>>14454089
you need to have several minor technological improvements in place. The person to combine those across fields of expertise. And finally a way to make it economically viable.

The mechanics to get a nice even pressure for the imprinting, good quality ink, fine iron lettering, the paper to make it economically viable and finally a costumer base to unload all those prints onto.

In the west a large pert of the cost of a book was in the parchment en vellum used as writing surface. This meant that the cost of a copyist was not the largest part of the cost. And since the cost was quite high it was a luxury product so splurging on a luxury finish was part of it, a thing harder to do with a print version.
So it took until cheaper fiber paper and a larger merchant class with a desire to read to get print going.

>>14454643
okay so you don't quite get it
you pulling the lever needs to spread the pressure even along the entire surface you want to print on and do so consistently
secondly the engraving or lettering needs to precise and clear enough to print well the same without irregularities like ink clots or fading patches
then the paper you are printing on needs to not have ink "running" or "spilling" along the fibers.
The paper preferably also allows for printing on two sides so it can't bleed any ink to the other side
As for the ink you can't use liquid ink for this process because it will not print crisply so you need more of an ink paste and you guessed it it can't get in between the lettering or your print is fucked

And now consider that your average page take about 2000 letter nowadays a bit less back then but say 1500 letters. So if your error margin is just 1 percent you've still got 15 faults so trash it and start over. Now do this on the other side, faults? trash both sides and start over. And do this say a 200 more times.
Oh and do keep in mind that your book still has to be bound and that involves needle and tread and possibly hot glue. So you need to keep your margins uniform and nice or you are going to fuck it up while binding. Hot glue can also mess with the ink.
And you can't use the standard cheap ink back then because that thin is acidic and will eat your paper in just a few years, not that much of a problem when you are writing on procesed animal hide tough. No you'd need the fancy import ink that cost quite a bit.

Those are just a few things I had to keep in mind wile and printing, finishing and then binding at a professional bookbinders shop.
Now I work at a publisher. We now have super fancy digital printers ect. And we still get faults.

You thing printing is easy because you've never fucking done it.
It's like "just make gunpowder lol" yes good fun until you blow your self up because you used a stone mortar and pestle to grind it up.

>>14456000
Merlin wasn't always depicted as the ostensibly magical wizard that he is usually thought of as. The character was presumably based on a composite of two men named Myrddin Wyllt (A Caledonian or northern Briton prophet or madman of sorts, or both, but not really the wizard type), and Ambrosius Aurelianus (Said to be a relative of King Arthur in most of the original versions). If Merlin existed, this character was probably most closely that of Myrddin Wyllt, who may or may not have been an orthodox-enough Christian, and decidedly not an occult sorcerer.

that's also why modern scholars are more inclined towards the interpretation that the motive of demak attack to 'majapahit' was not religious. but rather a political move by raden patah to wrestle back his father's kingdom (and therefore his righful kingdom) from the usurper. the islamization of java was just a nice big bonus of it.

posts.sub: The Sub-Standard performance of the 24th Regiment in Korea
posts.com:
>On 30 November, the 24th was at Kunu-ri, with Chinese troops behind it. The battalion extricated itself, losing 110 troops, 30 wounded. Overall, the 24th lost one-fifth of its officers and one-third of its enlisted men in the withdrawal across the Chong'chon River.
>On 6 March, The 1/24th was re-manned and did well, moving over difficult terrain against an entrenched enemy. The 3rd Battalion initially also performed well, executing a hastily devised river crossing and advancing through rough country against well dug-in PVA troops, far from the 1st Battalion. While climbing up steep terrain, however, the 1/24th reportedly collapsed under Chinese fire and withdrew in disorder. When the Division commander learned of that action, his confidence in the 24th plummeted. Many soldiers of the 24th ran away from the fighting, tossing their weapons and equipment aside. A derisive poem throughout the U.S. Army stated: 'When the Chinaman's mortars begins to thud, the Deuce-Four Niggers begin to bug.'
>Although the 24th performed well in the attack north of the Han and the subsequent general withdrawal of the Eighth Army after the Chinese Spring Offensive of 1951, its reputation was somewhat tarnished. But it performed well in the Army's drive back north in May and June 1951. In September 1950, the 24th's division commander, Gen. William B. Kean, requested that it be disbanded because it was "untrustworthy and incapable of carrying out missions expected of an infantry regiment." By 1 October 1951, the 24th was dissolved.

Read the response I made for >>14451067. I already addressed what you just wrote.

Deification (Theosis) is the ancient theological word used to describe the process by which a Christian becomes more like God. St. Peter speaks of this process when he writes, “As His divine power has given to us all things that pertain to life and godliness . . . you may be partakers of the divine nature”.

What does it mean to partake of the divine nature, and how do we experience this? To give an answer, let us first address what deification is not, and then describe what it is.

What deification is not. When the Church calls us to pursue godliness, to be more like God, this does not mean that human beings become divine. We do not become like God in His nature. That would not only be heresy, it would be impossible. For we are human, always have been human, and always will be human. We cannot take on the nature of God.

St. John of Damascus makes a remarkable observation. The word “God” in the Scriptures refers not to the divine nature or essence, for that is unknowable. “God” refers rather to the divine energies—the power and grace of God that we can perceive in this world. The Greek word for God, theos, comes from a verb meaning “run,” “see,” or “burn.” These are energy words, so to speak, not essence words.

In John 10:34, Jesus, quoting Psalm 81:6, repeats the passage, “You are gods.” The fact that He was speaking to a group of hypocritical religious leaders who were accusing Him of blasphemy makes the meaning doubly clear: Jesus is not using “god” to refer to divine nature. We are gods in that we bear His image, not His nature.

>>14451118
Because of the Incarnation of the Son of God, because the fullness of God has inhabited human flesh, being joined to Christ means that it is again possible to experience deification, the fulfillment of our human destiny. That is, through union with Christ, we become by grace what God is by nature—we “become children of God” (Jn 1:12). His deity interpenetrates our humanity.

Historically, deification has often been illustrated by the example of a sword in the fire. A steel sword is thrust into a hot fire until the sword takes on a red glow. The energy of the fire interpenetrates the sword. The sword never becomes fire, but it picks up the properties of fire.

By application, the divine energies interpenetrate the human nature of Christ. When we are joined to Christ, our humanity is interpenetrated with the energies of God through Christ’s glorified flesh. Nourished by the Body and Blood of Christ, we partake of the grace of God—His strength, His righteousness, His love—and are enabled to serve Him and glorify Him. Thus we, being human, are being deified.

Part final

>Sendero’s rhetoric, shaped above all by Guzmán, deployed a distinctive combination of dry dogma and apocalyptic imagery. A document produced by its conference in December 1979 asserted that ‘our party forged with the strongest light and the purest steel had a decisive moment and generated the National Construction Plan ... the communists rose up and the earth shook and as the earth shook the comrades advanced.’ At the 1988 Party Congress, held clandestinely in Lima, Guzmán said that ‘the soul of the party begins to burn even hotter, even louder, illuminating the skies and melting the earth ... Legions of iron will converge in a red sea, armed, rolling across the earth, shaking and upending it.’ The verb barrer, ‘to sweep away’, appears frequently in Sendero’s statements, reflecting an almost millenarian commitment to smashing the existing political and social system.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14455324
>This was one reason Sendero’s message resonated with many campesinos, or peasant farmers: its arrival in an area often meant the removal or even execution of the local authorities, the varayoq (literally ‘staff-holders’), a male-dominated chain of ceremonial posts that often reflected economic imbalances. Sendero detachments – in which women played leading roles, unlike in most villages or indeed on the rest of the Peruvian left – would install a new ‘popular committee’ to run village affairs, and would often administer summary justice to cattle thieves, drunks, wife beaters and corrupt officials ... But the war wasn’t fought only in the Andes. From early on, Sendero had established a presence in the poor neighbourhoods of Lima, and as its influence increased it began to direct its fire against community organisations, NGOs and the rest of the Peruvian left. Not only did Sendero not want allies; it targeted other leftists for intimidation or assassination. Its detachments were often armed with little more than rocks, machetes or sticks of dynamite they had stolen from foreign mining concessions. More than once they loaded donkeys with explosives and sent them into crowded marketplaces (these were known as burrobombas; other homemade devices included the queso ruso, ‘Russian cheese’, a crude bomb with a timer). All told, according to the final report of Peru’s Truth and Reconciliation Commission, issued in 2003, Sendero was responsible for 46 per cent of casualties in the war, making it an unusually lethal guerrilla army – and an exception to the worldwide norm. In most cases, government forces are responsible for the lion’s share of deaths in civil conflicts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14455332
>How and why was an apparently fringe movement able to pose such a serious and sustained challenge to the Peruvian state? The question has perplexed Latin America experts almost since the insurgency began. ‘Senderologists’ face the problem of explaining where the movement came from in the first place, and why it took such a different path from the rest of the Peruvian and Latin American left. Not only did Sendero take up arms when the country’s other leftists had settled on the electoral route; it also went against prevailing trends in the region as a whole, since – Central America aside – this was a moment when much of the Latin American left had turned away from guerrilla warfare. Sendero went against the tide in its Maoism, too: Mao had died in 1976, and China had begun its ‘reform and opening up’ two years later (hence the animus against Deng Xiaoping). Yet Sendero’s very status as a historical and political anomaly – seemingly out of place, out of time – only deepens the enigma. Given how extraneous to Peruvian realities the insurgency seemed to be, how was it able to gain a foothold, and to last as long as it did?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14455339
>In some ways, Sendero’s doctrinal inflexibility and its distance – physical and ideological – from the rest of the Peruvian left were assets early on, allowing it to develop an unusual cohesion and consistency of outlook. These features would eventually be subordinated to a grotesque cult of personality, in which Guzmán – ‘President Gonzalo’ – was hailed as the ‘Fourth Sword of Marxism’ (after Marx, Lenin and Mao). But in the meantime they had made Sendero a formidably disciplined political and military force. This is especially striking given that, unlike many other guerrilla insurgencies, Sendero had no practical support at all from outside the country; according to Starn and La Serna, most of its shoestring budget came from tuition fees from a small private school in Lima (they reject the idea that Sendero made fortunes from the drug trade in the Huallaga Valley). There is another respect in which its isolation made a difference. Much of the global left experienced perestroika, the fall of the Berlin Wall and Tiananmen Square as deep ideological shocks, prompting a re-evaluation of strategy as well as basic principles. Sendero by contrast saw these events as confirmation of its worldview: it had already identified both the USSR and China as ‘revisionist’ powers hostile to the true revolutionary cause, and now destined for the same scrapheap of history as the capitalist world.

The insurgency took place at a moment of great tension in the Peruvian countryside...

Marriage fulfils three functions. Social, Religious, and Political/Economic. The religious aspect should be outside the realm of government - and if a church wants to preform a ceremony for gay couples then that's a matter for that church's leadership and congregation. The social aspect is to announce to your friends and family that you think that this relationship is the one you want to keep from now on (although given divorce stats there's some debate about how much this applies now), but again that's not something that you need a government's or church's permission for, just throw a party and announce it. The reason that marriage has legislation around it is for the last one there, the economic factor. A stable, loving, supportive heterosexual family has been proven time and time again to be the best scenario to breed and produce children (the next generation of citizens and workers, hence the government's interest in it). There isn't sufficient data to tell us how gay parents will compare to that just yet - and for such a polarising issue it is almost impossible for a fair and honest study to be conducted/published - but let's be real and acknowledge that at its best it can only be as good as a functional heterosexual marriage, just without the ability to actually breed their own children.

As such it is, in the absolute best possible case, a second rate set up for fulfilling the task of a marriage (from the perspective of the government, the people you are arguing should be involved). Why are you in favour of the state wasting its limited and already overstretched resources on an, at best, second rate set up OP? Your fee-fees are not a political issue. Grow up. Enjoy life with your homosexual partner and stop trying to bother the rest of us.

And so, one bright fall day in 1969, Nixon met with Soviet ambassador Andrei Dobrynin in the White House. It was not their first encounter; that was on February 17, barely a month into the new administration, where Nixon urged the ambassador to work out a system whereby potentially volatile geopolitical situations could be defused before they blew up into armed conflict. As the months passed, he got no useful response from Moscow concerning Berlin, the Middle East, and above all, Vietnam.

The president had understandably been frustrated with the lack of progress on US-Soviet relations and he used some decidedly colorful language in this meeting. "As of today (October 20, 1969) I've been in office nine months. The babies should have been born by now. Instead there have been several miscarriages," Nixon began before he went on to rattle off a list of Soviet "sins" particularly in Vietnam, where he believed they were obstructing the peace process. "Mr. Ambassador, I want you to understand that the Soviet Union is going to be stuck with me for the next three years and three months, and during all that time I will keep in mind what is being done right now, today. The whole world wants us to get together. I too want nothing so much as to have my administration remembered as a watershed in US-Soviet relations. But let me repeat that we will not hold still for being diddled to death in Vietnam."

After uttering that last sentence, Nixon declared the meeting adjourned and had Kissinger escort Dobrynin out the door. Afterwards, the Secretary of State exclaimed "I wager nobody's ever talked like that to him in his whole career. It was extraordinary. No president has ever laid it on the line to them like that!"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
To show he meant business, the president asked for Congress to approve an anti-ballistic missile system as a necessary bargaining chip. A Democrat Congress widely infected with antiwar sentiment was less than enthusiastic but Nixon arm-twisted the plan through Congress. It passed the Senate by a single vote--when Vice President Agnew provided the tiebreaker. Moscow chafed at this strong-armed action as they would be forced to spend resources on their own ABM system, and they knew Nixon meant business.

The next great move came nearly three years later when, on May 20, 1972, Nixon became the first sitting president to visit the Kremlin (FDR had set foot on Soviet soil at Yalta). He was installed in a entire floor of the Grand Palace of the Kremlin as he prepared to meet with Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev and an interpreter. Nixon quickly realized that Brezhnev was no pushover; he was a formidable negotiator, and he wrote in his diary "Anyone who dismisses [Brezhnev] as either a fool or a simplistic brute is making a mistake."

Here was an important aspect of Nixon's diplomatic skills; he knew that communist leaders were tough characters and not to be underestimated, and in his negotations with them always treated them politely, respectfully, and did not talk down to them. Dmitri Simes, who was a Soviet policy advisor at the Moscow Institute of World Economy in 1972, praised Nixon as a negotiator. He was tough, but all business. "[Nixon] didn't go into lofty polemics or scolding about human rights and democracy as President Carter did. He talked in a language they understood, about strength and national interest."

posts.name: Anonymous

The Soviets were eager to see how much they could get away with. At one point during the first round of negotiations, Brezhnev casually cut 185 miles from the agreed limits as to how far the new Soviet ABM system would be situated from Moscow. Nixon noticed this right away, chewed Brezhnev out over it, and the Soviet leader immediately did a 180 and mentioned the original agreed limit as if the whole bait-and-switch had never happened.

Next up was Vietnam. Here Brezhnev decided to lull Nixon into a trap. He casually suggested a friendly sit-down at his dacha after dinner, Nixon being unaware that it was a staged plan to condemn the entire US war effort in Indochina. "It was like Jekyll and Hyde how Brezhnev was laughing and joking one minute, and the next minute his face turned red and he started into a tirade about Vietnam." Brezhnev, Kosygin, and Podgorny engaged in a chorus of accusations and denunciations. "Four hundred Vietnamese schoolchildren die each month in American bombing raids!" "How do you explain what happened at My Lai?" "American war crimes in Vietnam rival the worst things the Nazis did!" and so on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Although Nixon could lose his temper over trivial reasons, he was thoroughly unimpressed by the Soviet leaders and stared at them stony-faced as they paced around the room ranting and raving. He interrupted their diatribe only with the occasional one sentence remark like "Is this a threat you're making?" At length he got his speaking turn, and he calmly proceeded to refute the Soviet accusations. Since taking office three years ago, he'd pulled 500,000 US military personnel from Indochina, he'd been nothing short of diplomatic in his peace-making efforts, and he'd merely responded in kind to North Vietnamese attacks and provocations against the South.

Finally, having emptied their cannons of all the shells they could muster, Brezhnev and Co. calmed down, became cheerful, and all parties had a splendid state dinner. Kissinger would express his awe at how unflappable Nixon had been in the face of the Soviet leaders' temper tantrum over Vietnam.
